citeinfo.origin: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service (digital compiler)
citeinfo.title: WATERSHEDS_HUC10_2009_USDA_IN: Ten-digit Watershed Boundaries for Indiana (United States Department of Agriculture, 1:24,000 Polygon Shapefile)
citeinfo.othercit: These metadata are a revision of a metadata file named "wbdhu10_a_in.xml" published on September 23, 2009, by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Cartography and Geospatial Center, for a polygon shapefile entitled, "wbdhu10_a_in.shp."

descript.abstract:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"This data set is a complete digital hydrologic unit boundary layer to the Watershed (10-digit) 5th level for the NRCS business areas in and around the state of Indiana. This data set consists of geo-referenced digital data and associated attributes created in accordance with the "Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3" (04/01/2009). http://www.ncgc.nrcs.usda.gov/products/data sets/watershed/index.html . Polygons are attributed with hydrologic unit codes for 4th level sub-basins, 5th level watersheds, name, size, downstream hydrologic unit, type of watershed, noncontributing areas and flow modification."
descript.purpose:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"The Watershed and Subwatershed hydrologic unit boundaries provide a uniquely identified and uniform method of subdividing large drainage areas. The smaller sized 6th level sub-watersheds (up to 250,000 acres) are useful for numerous application programs supported by a variety of local, State, and Federal Agencies. This data set is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies requiring a level of detail provided by large-scale map information. The data set is seamless and, for the most part, a nationally consistant geospatial database."
descript.supplinf:
These metadata are a revision of a metadata file named "wbdhu10_a_in.xml" published on September 23, 2009, by the U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Cartography and Geospatial Center, for a polygon shapefile entitled, "wbdhu10_a_in.shp."
For more information on the Watershed Boundary data set, please see the following Web site:
<http://www.ncgc.nrcs.usda.gov/products/data sets/watershed/datainfo.html>

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows 7 Enterprise; ESRI ArcGIS 10.0 (Build 2800), approximately 13.3 MB

attracc.attraccr:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"Attribute:Accuracy Report: 10% of the Attributes were visually reviewed. The accuracy of this data is dependent on the level of detail of the source material and the interpretation procedures for capturing that source."

dataqual.logic:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"There are no unclosed polygons, intersections without nodes, or polygons without labels or with more than one label. The ArcGIS geodatabase topology tools were used to make corrections using 11 rules including no gaps, no overlaps, identify cooresponding linework for every polygon boundary, and remove duplicate lines with the same beginning and ending nodes."
dataqual.complete:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"All fields for all polygons are attributed. Some polygons in the Ncontrb_a field might have a 0 value."

horizpa.horizpar:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"The WBD was produced using Digital Raster Graphics (DRGs) as the source map. Data completeness for DRG files reflects content of the source graphic and may therefore be reflected in the completeness and accuracy of the WBD. The map was digitized from USGS 1:24,000-scale digital raster graphic base maps, with an inherited error of +/- 40 feet according to the USGS National Map Accuracy Standards. It is estimated that any errors detected were less than 10%. It should also be noted that while general rules of hydrology were used (i.e. natural water flow is downhill), the locations of boundaries are still somewhat subjective as the 1:24,000-scale DRGs do not always provide enough information for identifying the location of the boundaries."

srcinfo.srccontr: Hydrologic unit map delineation and digitizing
Hydrologic unit map delineation and digitizing
GIS raster coverage used for reference in watershed boundary delineation
GIS coverage used for reference in watershed boundary delineation

procstep.procdesc: The original hydrologic unit boundaries were hand-digitized on a tablet from the USGS 7.5-minute quadrangles. This process occurred over a span of approximately 20 years.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service

procstep.procdesc: The original data set was reviewed by USGS personnel using on-screen techniques with DRGs as the base map. All hydrologic units within the data set that were less than 3,000 acres were dissolved out.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service

procstep.procdesc: The new WBD data set was reviewed on-screen by USGS, EPA, or NRCS personnel using DRGs and DOQs as base maps. Hydrologic Units that were less than 40,000 acres (for the 10-digit units) were reviewed, and, if possible, were dissolved out. Along the coastal areas classic watersheds that fell within the federal guidelines size criteria (10-digit: 40,000-250,000 acres) were broken out. If possible the remaining frontals were left as their own units. Hydrologic units what were greater than 250,000 acres (10-digit units) were reviewed. If possible these units were then broken down into smaller units that met the size criteria.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service

procstep.procdesc: Hydrologic units from surrounding states were used to edgematch watershed boundaries.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation

procstep.procdesc: Original data set attribution was reviewed and revised to reflect the updates and changes made to the data set. These revisions to the attribution were also made to ensure that the data set met the Federal Standards for Delineation of Hydrologic Unit Boundaries. The NHD was used during this process to help with the naming and downstream coding of each unit. In some instances there were name hydrologic unit name discrepancies between the NHD and what was printed on the DRGs. In these instances the DRGs were used instead of the NHD. The 12-digit watershed boundaries were used to dissolve to the 10-digit scale using the HUC10 attribute.

cntperp.cntorg: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation

procstep.procdesc: ESRI ArcGIS10 ArcToolbox was used to "Select By Location" all 10-digit watersheds that fell within or intersected the Indiana state border from the national watershed boundary data set, named wbdhu10_a_in.shp. The shapefile was saved under the new name of "WATERSHEDS_HUC10_2009_USDA_IN.shp" Deleted empty field "HU_10_GNIS."

cntperp.cntorg: Center for Geospatial Data Analysis, Indiana Geological Survey

procstep.procdesc: This metadata file was pre-parsed and parsed using CNS (Chew and Spit, v. 2.6.1) and MP (Metadata Parser, v. 2.7.1) software written by Peter N. Schweitzer (United States Geological Survey). The errors generated by MP were all addressed and corrected.

cntperp.cntorg: Center for Geospatial Data Analysis, Indiana Geological Survey

enttyp.enttypds: Center for Geospatial Data Analysis, Indiana Geological Survey

attr.attrdef: Internal feature number
attr.attrdefs: ESRI

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated

attr.attrdef: Feature geometry
attr.attrdefs: ESRI

attr.attrdef: Eight-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code: A unique 8-digit code from the USGS map series "Hydrologic Unit Maps." The same number was used in every record that pertains to a subwatershed that resides within the same 8-digit sub-basin.Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: Ten-Digit Hydrologic Unit Code: This field provides a unique 10-digit code for each watershed. This same number was used in every record that pertains to a subwatershed that resides within the same 10-digit watershed. Numbers were assigned in an upstream to downstream fashion. Where no downstream/upstream relationship could be determined numbers were assigned in a clockwise fashion.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: Area of subwatershed including noncontributing areas calculated to acres as a whole number, no decimals. The "Acres" field was calculated from the "Area" field.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: noncontributing Area: Drainage areas that do not flow toward the outlet of any hydrologic unit are considered noncontributing. If a noncontributing area is on the boundary between two or more hydrologic units, the noncontributing area is associated with the hydrologic unit adjacent to the low point on the boundary. This attribute should be the total of the noncontributing areas within a hydrologic unit calculated in acres.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: Fifth-Level Downstream Hydrologic Unit Code: This field has the 10-digit code of the 5th-level hydrologic unit that is receiving the majority of the flow from the watershed that the 6th-level HU falls within. Outlets created by ditching or other artificial drainage were not considered for this field. If an HU flows into an ocean or the Gulf of Mexico, this field was populated with "OCEAN" and if a HU flows into one of the Great Lakes the term "LAKE" was used. If a HU flows across international borders, "CANADA" or "MEXICO" was used depending on which country the HU drains into. If an HU is a closed basin, then the term "CLOSED BASIN"was used.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: Fifth-Level Hydrologic Unit Name: This field used officially recognized names only. This field was populated by following the directions in subsection 6.3 "Watershed and Subwatershed Naming Protocol." The name used to attribute the watershed was used only once within a 4th-level unit.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

attr.attrdef: Fifth-Level Hydrologic Unit Modifications: This field identifies any type of modifications to natural overland flow that alters the location of the hydrologic unit boundary for a 10-digit watershed. This field shows the most significant to least significant modification(s) to the watershed boundary. One or more of the following abbreviations was used.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: Fifth-Level Hydrologic Unit Type: This field was populated with the hydrologic unit type from the list provided that most closely identifies the watershed.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

edom.edomvd: "Standard" hydrologic unit - Any land HU with drainage flowing to a single outlet point, excluding non-contributing areas. This includes areas or small triangular wedges between adjacent HUs that remain after classic hydrologic units are delineated. Some examples include "true," "classic," "composite," and "remnant" hydrologic units.
edom.edomvds: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

edom.edomvd: "Multiple Outlet" hydrologic unit - An area that has more than one natural outlet; for example, an outlet located on a stream with multiple channels. This does not include frontal or water hydrologic units, hydrologic units with artificial interbasin transfers, drainage outlets through karst or ground-water flow, or outlets that cross a stream with an island. This code should be used only in rare instances.
edom.edomvds: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

edom.edomvd: "Frontal" hydrologic unit - Areas along the coastline of lakes, oceans, bays, etc., that have more than one outlet. These HUs are predominantly land with some water areas at or near the outlet(s).
edom.edomvds: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3

attr.attrdef: The Metadata ID Number is a code that identifies which metadata file applies to the line or polygon. In most cases there is only one metadata file. However, in some cases more than one metadata file was used to identify different groups and/or procedures used to produce the lines or polygons. The metadata ID is a 4-character code starting with the 2-letter state postal code, followed by a 2-digit sequence number. For example "OK01," "ID02," etc.
attr.attrdefs: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

attr.attrdef: Denotes record edits by National Cartography and Geospatial Center
attr.attrdefs: US Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service

attr.attrdef: The name of the first level of classification divides the nation into 21 major geographic areas
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: The name of the second level of classification divides the 21 regions into 222 subregions
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: The name of third level of classification subdivides many of the subregions into Basins
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: The name of the fourth level of classification of a Hydrologic Unit
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: 2-digit (1st-level) code used for the HU Region
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: 4-digit (2nd-level) code used for Subregions
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: 6-digit (3rd-level) code used for Basins
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

attr.attrdef: Total square mile area for the subbasin (8-digit; 4th level)
attr.attrdefs: Hydrologic Unit Maps; USGS Water Supply Paper 2294

overview.eaover: Each hydrologic unit polygon has associated attributes stored in tabular format. An attribute, also called a field or column, is defined by name, type, size, and valid values. For this layer, these attributes are the Hydrologic Unit Codes, Names, Acreage, States crossed, non-contributing area, Downstream unit code, Type, and Modification. <ftp://ftp-fc.sc.egov.usda.gov/NCGC/products/watershed/hu-standards.pdf>
overview.eadetcit: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary data set; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3.

distinfo.distliab:
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"None."
LIMITATION OF LIABILITY
The following is extracted from USDA, NRCS metadata --
"The distributor shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of this data, based on the description of appropriate/inappropriate uses described in this metadata document. It is strongly recommended that this data is directly acquired from the distributor and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. These data should not be used at scales greater than 1:24,000 for the purpose of identifying hydrographic watershed boundary feature locations in the U.S.A. The U.S. Department of Agriculture makes no claims for the suitability of the data for other purposes. U.S. Department of Agriculture should be acknowledged as the data source in products derived from these data. The Watershed Boundary data set is public information and may be interpreted by all organizations, agencies, units of government, or others based on needs; however, they are responsible for the appropriate application of the data. Federal, State, or local regulatory bodies are not to reassign to the U.S. Department of Agriculture or the Natural Resources Conservation Service any authority for the decisions they make. The Natural Resources Conservation Service will not perform any evaluations of these maps or purposes related solely to State or local regulatory programs. Photographic or digital enlargement of these maps to scales greater than that at which they were originally delineated can result in misrepresentation of the data. If enlarged, the maps will not include the fine detail that would be appropriate for mapping at the small scale. Digital data files are periodically updated. Files are dated, and users are responsible for obtaining the latest version of the data from the source distributor."
DATA DISCLAIMER
This data set was compiled by Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey, using data believed to be accurate; however, a degree of error is inherent in all data. This product is distributed "AS-IS" without warranties of any kind, either expressed or implied, including but not limited to warranties of suitability to a particular purpose or use. No attempt has been made in either the design or production of these data to define the limits or jurisdiction of any federal, state, or local government. These data are intended for use only at the published scale or smaller and are for reference purposes only. They are not to be construed as a legal document or survey instrument. A detailed on-the-ground survey and historical analysis of a single site may differ from these data.
WARRANTY
Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey warrants that the media on which this product is stored will be free from defect in materials and workmanship for ninety (90) days from the date of acquisition. If such a defect is found, return the media to Publication Sales, Indiana Geological Survey, 611 North Walnut Grove Avenue, Bloomington, Indiana 47405 2208, and it will be replaced free of charge.
LIMITATION OF WARRANTIES AND LIABILITY
Except for the expressed warranty above, the product is provided "AS IS", without any other warranties or conditions, expressed or implied, including, but not limited to, warranties for product quality, or suitability to a particular purpose or use. The risk or liability resulting from the use of this product is assumed by the user. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey shares no liability with product users indirect, incidental, special, or consequential damages whatsoever, including, but not limited to, loss of revenue or profit, lost or damaged data or other commercial or economic loss. Indiana University, Indiana Geological Survey is not responsible for claims by a third party. The maximum aggregate liability to the original purchaser shall not exceed the amount paid by you for the product.

metainfo.metuc: This metadata file is intended to accompany the data set identified and received from the IGS. It should not to be altered or summarized. IGS does not support secondary distribution. If this data set was received from anyone besides the IGS, this metadata file and the data set it describes may lack integrity.
